channel.title: Is it possible to stretch a muscle?
channel.description: Okay, at Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu training this afternoon, I was practicing putting an armbar on the opponent from Guard, and my friend did it too me, and ever since that my forearm (that's mainly were it bars) has been really tight. When I move it a slight bit it feels like my muscle stretches, and it has no strength. I felt a really big pulling sensation when he had me in the armbar lock, but I didn't notice it until I got home and began typing.

item.title: Is it possible to stretch a muscle?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“io9, post:14, topic:248820”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=327937.msg2568274#msg2568274 date=1228513100]

Knee bars are better…

I don’t recall asking which joint lock was better. Kneebar’s maybe are stronger, in terms of pain/injury caused, but they’re harder to apply than the armbar, and the armbar can be practically modified to bar in any direction, where as the kneebar only works one way, hyper extension, and since the armbar can be backwards, and you can easily turn that into a Kimura hold, using the elbow joint to your advantage.
[/quote]
Who cares you still have no bike l0lolol-0ol0ol0ol0ol0ol0ol.[/quote]
Hi io9, go back to fat camp.
[center] You didn’t need to, you know.[/center]

Read full topic
item.source: Is it possible to stretch a muscle?

Kneebar’s maybe are stronger, in terms of pain/injury caused, but they’re harder to apply than the armbar, and the armbar can be practically modified to bar in any direction, where as the kneebar only works one way, hyper extension, and since the armbar can be backwards, and you can easily turn that into a Kimura hold, using the elbow joint to your advantage.[/quote]I was just throwin’ it out there. I just can’t put someone in an armbar but i can get someone in a kneebar. I know hardly any Jiu-Jitsu, just some basic moves some friends of mine taught me in gym.

item.title: Is it possible to stretch a muscle?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:6, topic:248820”][quote author=Efilite link=topic=327937.msg2568011#msg2568011 date=1228503319]
You realize that arm will be stronger when the muscles have, repaired
[/quote]

Uh, no.[/quote]

This is one time when you’re wrong. Davidude36 is right, muscles tear, and when they ‘repair’ they are stronger. The scar tissue or whatever you want to call it bulks the muscle up.

Read full topic

item.title: Is it possible to stretch a muscle?
item.dc:creator: @Efilite Efilite
item.description:
@Efilite wrote:

Yz85Racer:

Okay, at Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu training this afternoon, I was practicing putting an armbar on the opponent from Guard, and my friend did it too me, and ever since that my forearm (that’s mainly were it bars) has been really tight. When I move it a slight bit it feels like my muscle stretches, and it has no strength. I felt a really big pulling sensation when he had me in the armbar lock, but I didn’t notice it until I got home and began typing.

You realize that arm will be stronger when the muscles have, repaired, anyway yes. You can stretch a muscle.
I phoned my doctor.

Read full topic
item.source: Is it possible to stretch a muscle?

item.title: Is it possible to stretch a muscle?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

Yz85Racer:

Okay, at Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu training this afternoon, I was practicing putting an armbar on the opponent from Guard, and my friend did it too me, and ever since that my forearm (that’s mainly were it bars) has been really tight. When I move it a slight bit it feels like my muscle stretches, and it has no strength. I felt a really big pulling sensation when he had me in the armbar lock, but I didn’t notice it until I got home and began typing.

you might have just over exerted the muscle, causing it to tighten up so it can reapir itself. Just give it a few days and it should be ok. But if its not you may have strained the muscle, surely Jiu-Jitsu you should learn this sort of thing? When i used to do karate that was one of the first things we learned.

Read full topic
